caption: Figure 1: A description of bounding ||H₁ – P||tv via W(H₁) and OPT
description: This figure illustrates how the total variation distance ||H₁ – P||tv between a hypothesis H₁ and the true distribution P can be bounded using the semi-distance wᵢ*(Hᵢ) and OPT (the distance between P and the closest hypothesis Hᵢ* in H).  The triangle inequality shows that ||H₁ – P||tv ≤ ||H₁ – Hᵢ*||tv + ||Hᵢ* – P||tv.  The semi-distance wᵢ*(Hᵢ) is defined as |Hᵢ(Sᵢ,ⱼ) - P(Sᵢ,ⱼ)|, where Sᵢ,ⱼ is the Scheffé set for Hᵢ and Hᵢ*. The figure demonstrates that wᵢ*(Hᵢ) is a lower bound for ||Hᵢ – P||tv, and W(Hᵢ) (the maximum semi-distance for Hᵢ) is used as a proxy for the quality of Hᵢ because it is an upper bound for wᵢ*(Hᵢ).

caption: Figure 1. A description of bounding ||H₁ – P||tv via W(H₁) and OPT
description: This figure illustrates how the total variation distance ||H₁ – P||tv between a hypothesis H₁ and the true distribution P can be bounded using the score function W(H₁) and the optimal distance OPT.  It shows that wj(Hi) (the semi-distance) is always a lower bound for ||H₁ – P||tv. The figure highlights the triangle inequality relationship among ||H₁ – P||tv, ||H₁ – Hi*||tv (where Hi* is the closest hypothesis to P), and OPT. It demonstrates that if wi* (Hi) is bounded by OPT, then H₁ is close to P. The main point is that even without knowing i* or OPT, the minimum distance estimate algorithm uses W(Hi) as a proxy for the quality of Hi and successfully bounds ||Ĥ – P||tv (where Ĥ is the output hypothesis) by 3OPT.
